text: This might need a lot more space (perhaps a blog article), but in short, if you think your counterparties on a Saturday afternoon on UK horse racing are the same people as 3am on AUS racing, you're wrong. If you think the same people betting on a Tuesday evening at Wolverhampton are the exact same crowd as betting on a Sunday meeting at Naas, you're wrong. Evening racing is a different crowd to weekday afternoon racing, and both are different to weekend racing. Greyhounds - day vs evening are different crowds, different biases. Football is pretty uniform across a league, but EPL betting crowds are fundamentally different to Championship, and definitely different to other leagues in Europe and elsewhere in the World.

elements.text: This might need a lot more space (perhaps a blog article), but in short, if you think your counterparties on a Saturday afternoon on UK horse racing are the same people as 3am on AUS racing, you're wrong. If you think the same people betting on a Tuesday evening at Wolverhampton are the exact same crowd as betting on a Sunday meeting at Naas, you're wrong. Evening racing is a different crowd to weekday afternoon racing, and both are different to weekend racing. Greyhounds - day vs evening are different crowds, different biases. Football is pretty uniform across a league, but EPL betting crowds are fundamentally different to Championship, and definitely different to other leagues in Europe and elsewhere in the World.

text: The problem is we think "horse racing" or "cricket" or "greyhounds" and smooth out. We might spot obvious differences like country or clear liquidity changes, but there absolutely 100% is a different set of people on the other side of the screen on different days and different hours of the day, and that manifests in how the market moves and develops.

elements.text: The problem is we think "horse racing" or "cricket" or "greyhounds" and smooth out. text: What started me down this train of thought was a) fundamentally as a fan of these sports, I know there are important differences in the races being run or matches being played and the people who are betting on it, and b) my equity curve can show distinct patterns based on day of week or time of day for some strategies that I suspect might be sensitive to how smart the people on the other side of the screen are

text: Is there a way to categorise races by day/evening, other than using the time of day?

elements.text: Is there a way to categorise races by day/evening, other than using the time of day?

text: Races do have grades and classes - even in greyhounds - that might be worth quantifying. First thing I look at on a card when betting for fun is the prize money: directly correlates to quality of competitor and how "soft" the race and the market might be in various ways.

elements.text: Races do have grades and classes - even in greyhounds - that might be worth quantifying. First thing I look at on a card when betting for fun is the prize money: directly correlates to quality of competitor and how "soft" the race and the market might be in various ways.

text:
Not sure I would know how to show BSP was more or less accurate over a time range or a day of the week. Either you have faith in it as a metric or not though surely? Same with those who consider Pinnacle closing lines (Buchdahl) as the "benchmark". It's either usable or not surely? If we get down the route of "BSP is inaccurate on Monday afternoons for dog racing" what kind of can of worms does that open for assessing EV?

I should probably say that I only really use profit as my measure of EV and don't really concern myself with estimating it (other than as deviation of current prices from my models) so I am probably not the best person to be discussing it.

I should probably say that I only really use profit as my measure of EV and don't really concern myself with estimating it (other than as deviation of current prices from my models) so I am probably not the best person to be discussing it.

text: Do all selections that have a BSP win 50% of the time, regardless of any other factor? Are there are other factors that mean sometimes those selections win 47% of the time, or 53% of the time? What about at 1.5? 3.0? 750? 1.01? 1000?

text: My point is, you can do the maths to calibrate it, and then you can pull out events by day of week and see if the calibrations change. I did this once in about 2014-2015 IIRC, and it was... interesting... I shall try and repeat all that work this weekend if I have time, and write it up.

text: Equity curve is also a fine measure, shows you're right, right? But is your equity curve different on different days of the week or evening vs afternoon? I know I have strategies that definitely worked better on some days than others, and a bit of digging definitely made me think there was some causal link there due to the markets (and the events!), being different to each other in interesting ways

text: OK maybe seeing a concrete analysis will help me get to grips with this. Just seems odd to me - we are talking about things are individually unknowable and unmeasurable. And all things have some degree of natural variation. I mean fair play to you if you can find some way of doing the numbers and using the results to your advantage.

text:
I am going to go out on a limb here and disagree, you would be trying to find a signal in a very noisy dataset and even if you do find one it will be weak, very weak.

The sharper the crowd / the sharper the market, yes, however that doesn't mean your models should be any different. The only variable that does get impacted by this is execution as adverse selection becomes a real problem.

elements.text:
I am going to go out on a limb here and disagree, you would be trying to find a signal in a very noisy dataset and even if you do find one it will be weak, very weak.

The sharper the crowd / the sharper the market, yes, however that doesn't mean your models should be any different. The only variable that does get impacted by this is execution as adverse selection becomes a real problem.

text: The late afternoon races after the main events have always been a playground for the mad bad and sad, punting crap races trying to recover losses. Evening racing has more amateurs involved, and back in the day "blue collar lunchtime" used to see short favs when they all went to the bookie to eat their sarnies. Dogs have the same sort of real world stuff too. Different yes, but I can't find enough that's concrete to do much about it.

text:
What value would you test though? Something like daily log loss or brier score backing all runners at BSP? Across how many years? If such an observable inefficiency ever existed, surely there would be enough smart money taking advantage of it to the extent that it would be very very short lived and thus the overall effect be smoothed out over time.
I'm just thinking out loud - feel free to tear strips off me.

elements.text:

I'm just thinking out loud - feel free to tear strips off me.

text: One caveat I want to add here: I’m talking pre-event, not in play. I don’t do any in play at all, but from what I’ve seen (and never analysed in any way), I think I’d expect most in play markets to not deviate much day by day or hour by hour. But that’s because of the counter parties involved. Pre-event, quite different though, I think.

text:
Trainers/owners are often looking to set up a gamble and get their horse ahead of the handicapper and this is much easier to do in the 0-50 quality races you see on the all weather in the evenings. This can lead to some big plunges on horses whose form do not seem to warrant the price.

It still happens in higher grade racing but with the liquidity and more form on show the price moves are less drastic
